content: There seems to be a lot of interest, so creating a topic for this
hey!
/me turns up the music in this zulip stream and hands out snacks and drinks

These are commonly used in some of the Rust Meetup groups. This is the most recent event I attended where breakout rooms were used for getting to know each other. https://www.meetup.com/Rust-Los-Angeles/events/276587775
@Doc Jones I really like the idea of "mentored sprints"
one thing I was going to note is that discord has audio-only rooms and stuff too
which could be a nice fit
I really like the idea of using a spacial chat service
makes it much more natural for large groups to separate into conversations and makes it easy to move between them
and after looking at the workadventu.re and gather.town websites I'm all excited about a potential rust-lang virtual office space
Yeah, I thought @Daniel Silverstone's suggeston sounded cool -- not sure what that was.
was it gather.town ?
I want an office room for the error handling project group

nikomatsakis said:

was it gather.town ?

I think daniel's suggestion was workadventu.re
Ralf recommended gather.town
I kind of want to get a VR headset now

Agreed. I've attended Office hours events that use the audio rooms on Discord. It also has a screen share feature. Group size is still a factor. But if the group is specific to a content topic that can also help to shape attendance.
the problem with VR headsets is they take a while to get used to, I still get headaches wearing one for more than an hour
(my partner is Extremely into VR)
but VR would be fun too
so is the foundation going to sponsor VR headsets to every rust contributor? ;D
I'm here

I think daniel's suggestion was workadventu.re

It was indeed - We have a workadventure for both floors of our real life office, and our own jitsi instance etc. which means you can "go to the office and have a meeting" from your laptop :grinning: You can go to the break room while you make a cup of tea at home, etc.
seems to be pretty easy to make a room for gather.town: https://gather.town/i/B0vejNJS
similarly: https://play.workadventu.re/@/ctcsh/social-hour/office
if anyone is interested in testing either of these services I created some rooms
@Jane Lusby I've pinged the relevant team lead on IRC, so hopefully I'll be able to get some info for you in the coming days.
awesome, ty Daniel

Jane Lusby said:

and after looking at the workadventu.re and gather.town websites I'm all excited about a potential rust-lang virtual office space

"office" sounds way too boring, why recreate that in the virtual space? let's make them nice virtual worlds with all sorts of fun stuff and spaceships. :D
Who says your office isn't a rainforest in a biodome in space?
I guess what I am really saying is, for many of us here Rust is not work time, and so at least I'd rather not "go to the office" for Rust stuff :)
I was just playing about with gather.town
kind of cool

We (at work) started with a gather.town virtual pub as our friday social space, before we moved on to a self-hosted workadventure for a virtual office. The technologies are much of a muchness, but workadventure look a bit more open-source friendly IIRC

RalfJ said:

I guess what I am really saying is, for many of us here Rust is not work time, and so at least I'd rather not "go to the office" for Rust stuff :)

The Rust Community
as in, a town full of buildings for the various teams
this sounds so cool people
I sort of want it to be a text adventure though :P

This is a proximity chat service that I've tried. https://spatial.chat/ Ultimately, the trial was unsuccessful, but it's a different idea than a virtual office that persists where one might drop in to leave notes or schedule meetings. The only concern that I would add is not letting the tool get in the way of the purpose for gathering. That's likely a different consideration for social hours versus things like office hours or mentoring.
I found this talk by Tania Allard on her experience developing the Mentored Sprints program. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SGUHyP8ki_Q
Cool!
Having a Rust village where every team / WG / ... lives in it's own house and can visit each other sounds really cool. Every time I think about this I want it a little bit more :)

nikomatsakis said:

I sort of want it to be a text adventure though :P

Ah, should we make a MUD/MUSH/MOO?
actually… that sounds kind of awesome...
of course our rust one needs to be called a MURK
“Multi User Rust Kavern"

The progress of this conversation is beyond amusing. How did we get from let's talk about how to include more people in engagement and mentoring to - wait! I know...let's build a game. :laughter_tears:
Speaking for the non-gaming devs of the world. You do you. LOL "hyperbole alert"
heh, I thought gamification was a proven method for driving engagement! ;)

pnkfelix said:

heh, I thought gamification was a proven method for driving engagement! ;)

For those who are gamers this is true. I think Meetup groups (there are a growing number of Rust specific monthly meetups) and Women Who Code leading mentoring and social gatherings outside a game construct are excellent examples of the options. Building a game versus starting a Zoom call or discord voice chat would create a delay and effort burden that I think volunteers would rather avoid. You are free to infer that this volunteer would be one of those avoiders. :grinning_face_with_smiling_eyes:
That’s a great point, thanks

(my comment was somewhat tongue-in-cheek, and of course there’s no reason to wait to do things like start Zoom calls or Discord voice chats. But the point you make remains a solid one: There is a significant population that won’t respond to gamification.)
I couldn't find a thank you emoji.
I've been curious about this previously: https://fosstodon.org/web/statuses/106110500743954306
though the question at hand isn't about 'recognition'
Wow! 78% responded "no thanks" That's a higher number than I would have predicted.

I admit my own surprise as well since there is a body or research related to this, this is a FOSS community being polled so that may have been the cause of divergence from what I think are general expectations that gamification works

pnkfelix said:

“Multi User Rust Kavern"

Community Rust Adventure Ballad (CRAB)

oliver said:

I admit my own surprise as well since there is a body or research related to this, this is a FOSS community being polled so that may have been the cause of divergence from what I think are general expectations that gamification works

Might also be good to look at what "works" means, because some forms of gamification are fun for those "playing" while other forms may increase engagement at the expense of those involved.
The concept of a shared adventure is fun to entertain, though I'd never want it to be a required participatory medium. But that survey was asking more about things like badges/achievements/etc.
I agree that there isn't a direct correlation between that poll to the question at hand
this doesn't really feel like gamification to me
@Jane Lusby I agree; that was what I was getting at.
like, gamifying this would be having an exp bar or inventory system or something on your avatar in the virtual meeting space
this is just using games technology to implement a conferencing system

"let's have a fun shared virtual space as an optional thing people can enjoy together" is very different than "let's add achievements and variable-reward mechanisms to make you want to code harder" :)
yea
I think "gamification" feels more strongly associated with the latter.
(I’m the one who first used the word “gamification”, which was, again, a tongue-in-cheek response to Doc Jones’ note.)
I think this is gamification of social interaction, incentivization would be related to recognition or rewards

Yeah, it sounds like effort into creating a space for social interaction is a separate thing from the mentoring program which would be best served by the least possible barriers to participation by people of various levels with some more easily intimidated than others. It's a challenge to create a shared experience with everyone here for the models used by Women Who Code and Mentored Sprints. I wish I could do that. Open to suggestions.

It might surprise you to hear that even with the excellent Awesome Rust mentors list I've found a cold reach out to connect to be a barrier for me.
I think at best the poll merely suggests that the ctcft equivalent of digital hats may not be enough to get that response you want
*results haven't been replicated ;)
I do want to say that I personally like gamification and I hope I'm not cursing anything good that may have come out of this, just ignore me :)
